Issues.Title: Refactor BindToObject
Issues.Body:
Essentially the `BindToObject` class is strangely connected to `Binding`. It seems to be designed to be used separately, but this just causes confusion as there are two different sources of truth that need to be (and are) synchronised. We can avoid this by

- Accessing properties on `Binding` and not exposing `BindToObject` to anyone outside of the `BindingClass` (commit 1-3)
- Moving properties from `BindToObject` to `Binding` which has central ownership of these properties
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Refactor BindToObject" (#854)

Issues.Title: IKeyboardToolTip implementation
Issues.Body: IKeyboardToolTip implementation added

Issues.Title: Add another option that works to make the classic designer work.
Issues.Body:
This is a issue for the pull request I just made #845.

The change in this Pull request documents another option that also makes the classic designer work. However it is a lazy way and works for all of the frameworks that the devpack can be installed for.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add another option that works to make the classic designer work." (#846)

Issues.Title: Added another option that works to make the classic designer work.
Issues.Body: This should now document all the ways I know of currently that work well for me (well the lazier way).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Added another option that works to make the classic designer work." (#845)

Issues.Title: Remove redundant defines
Issues.Body:
WIN95_SUPPORT - It is always defined in this project, which contains the only use of it.
WINDOWS_FORMS_SWITCHES - It is always defined, and build fails if it is not defined.

Relates to #39
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove redundant defines" (#838)

Issues.Title: Remove remaining CAS/transparency goo
Issues.Body:
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/40

Probably many of the "using System.Security;" can be removed, but I did not touch those. SecurityException can be thrown for non CAS reasons, and the code also throws some itself.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove remaining CAS/transparency goo" (#841)

Issues.Title: Remove part of remoting goo
Issues.Body:
Remove using statements, and the MarshalByRefObject derivations and lifetime override methods.

Contributes to https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/839

There is more left: quite a bit related to app domains certainly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Remove part of remoting goo" (#840)

Issues.Title: Remove dead Remoting and AppDomain goo
Issues.Body: .NET Core does not support Remoting, nor does it support secondary AppDomains. Therefore we should remove all code related to those things.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove dead Remoting and AppDomain goo" (#839)

This pull request implements the new `GetLParam<T>` and `GetLParamRef<T>` (#792) as internal methods, and uses them to avoid marshaling overhead for existing value types.

The first commit is shared with #818.

Issues.Title: Enable cross-thread checks by default
Issues.Body:
Cross-thread checks are disabled by default in Winforms, unless a debugger is attached or `Control.CheckForIllegalCrossThreadCalls` is explicitly set to true. I understand that back in the days it had been designed this way because it was a huge breaking change for .net 1.1 applications.

Now the landscape has changed quite a bit, and developers coming from WPF take those checks for granted and wrongly assume that they're activated by default in Winforms:
 - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3972727/why-is-cross-thread-operation-exception-not-thrown-while-running-exe-in-bin-debu
 - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55759792/why-are-we-allowed-to-modify-the-form-title-from-a-thread-pool-thread

I think this is a nice opportunity to fix this behavior and set `CheckForIllegalCrossThreadCalls` to true by default, as most developers would expect nowadays.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Enable cross-thread checks by default" (#832)

Issues.Title: `CodeDomSerializationProvider.GetSerializer(...)` is not implemented
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100-preview5-011362
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**

Currently, `System.ComponmentModel.Design.Serialization.CodeDomSerializationProvider.GetSerializer(...)` throws a `NotImplementedException`, blocking usage of the CodeDom serialization APIs:

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms.Design/src/System/ComponentModel/Design/Serialization/CodeDomSerializationProvider.cs#L15

It looks like this was probably just missed in the port, but it's one of the primary entry point into these APIs (via `DesignerSerializationManager`), so this needs to be implemented.

**Actual behavior:** Thows `NotImplementedException`

**Expected behavior:** Implemented and succeeds. :smile:
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "`CodeDomSerializationProvider.GetSerializer(...)` is not implemented" (#827)
